awd_abstract_narration:
The day-long Computational Structural Bioinformatics Workshop will bring together researchers and students working on a diverse set of problems including biomolecular structure representation, prediction, and alignment, biomolecule interaction and docking, and data mining and analysis of structural and genomics data. At the core of all these endeavors is the goal to establish and explore the relationships between protein sequence, structure, and function. The workshop will be held on December 09, 2021 and will coincide with the IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM). This award will support the development and dissemination of advances in computational structural bioinformatics, and will fund workshop registration for undergraduate and graduate students who are co-authors of manuscripts or poster abstracts accepted for presentation and inclusion in the conference proceedings.

A main objective of this workshop is to provide a forum for undergraduate and graduate students, and especially students from under-represented groups in computer science and bioinformatics, to present ongoing work, and to exchange project ideas and facilitate collaborations across labs and disciplines. The workshop will include several sessions for oral presentations of accepted manuscripts, as well as two poster sessions during which students will have the opportunity to explain their projects and answer questions. A career and hot topics round table discussion will provide students the opportunity to learn from each other and discuss current research challenges and opportunities. A synopsis of the student discussion session will be disseminated to the workshop website after the conclusion of the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Computational structural biology has contributed to scientific advances that have improved human health. Harnessing big data techniques and machine learning (ML) methods and models, computational structural biology has elucidated molecular interaction mechanisms. At the core of these goals, which are intrinsically structure-related, is the need to understand molecular mechanisms as they pertain to a variety of diseases.

Although there is a variety of molecular and structural biology conferences, only a handful of them explicitly solicit the participation of members from the computational community. To address this need, the Computational Structural Biology Workshop (CSBW) has been established with these three primary objectives: 1) discuss and share the most recent methods in the computational structural biology community, 2) provide a forum for undergraduate and graduate students to present ongoing work, in the form of manuscripts and posters, and 3) exchange project ideas and facilitate collaborations across labs and disciplines.

Dr. Negin Forouzesh (PI) and Dr. Kamal Al Nasr (Consultant) were the co-chairs of the 14th CSBW which was organized in an online modality in conjunction with the IEEE International Conference on Bioinformatics and Biomedicine (BIBM) in 2021. About 25 attendees, including four from Minority Serving Institutions, attended this one-day workshop on Dec. 11, 2021. The program started with a keynote speech entitled “Computational Structure Prediction and Therapeutic Design with Rosetta” by Dr. Jens Meiler (Vanderbilt University) followed by four technical sessions (13 short and full paper presentations) and two research highlights. To provide students and early-career faculty with the opportunity to learn from senior scholars, there was a virtual panel discussion about Industry and Academic Careers in Bioinformatics: Current Trends and Prospects for the Future. The three panelists were Dr. Amarda Shehu (George Mason University), Dr. Xia Ning (Ohia State University), and Dr. Negin Forouzesh (California State University, Los Angeles). The program details can be found on the CSBW website: https://facultyweb.cs.wwu.edu/~jagodzf/csbw/past.html

All the accepted papers were published in the conference proceedings available in the IEEE Xplore Digital Library. The authors were invited to publish the extended version of their manuscripts in the MDPI Biomolecules (IF: 6.064) Special Issue: Protein Modeling and Simulation. The PI and Consultant served as the guest editors of this special issue for one year. Eight full papers were published in this open-access journal among which five were financially supported by this NSF grant. More information about this special issue can be found here: https://www.mdpi.com/journal/biomolecules/special_issues/CSBW_2021

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Negin Forouzesh
